datasets.title: Regional GVA NUTS1
datasets.summary: Economic activity as measured by Gross Value Added (GVA)

statsBulletins.headline1: In 2012 Gross Value Added (GVA) per head of population increased in all NUTS1 regions except for the East Midlands.
statsBulletins.headline2: In 2012 the South East had the largest increase in GVA per head at 2.5%, followed by the North West at 1.7% and Wales at 1.6%.
statsBulletins.headline3: In 2012 London had the largest GVA per head at £37,232, while Wales had the lowest at £15,401.
statsBulletins.title: Regional Gross Value Added (Income Approach), December 2013
statsBulletins.summary: Shows economic activity as measured by Gross Value Added (GVA) for English regions, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland including component totals and industry group totals.

title: Gross Value Added (GVA)
summary: Gross Value Added (GVA) measures the contribution to the economy of each individual producer, industry or sector. In the UK it is used in the estimation of Gross Domestic Product (GDP).

breadcrumb.title: Home
breadcrumb.summary: The UK's largest independent producer of official statistics and the recognised national statistical institute of the UK.

breadcrumb.title: Economy
breadcrumb.summary: An economy or economic system consists of the production, distribution, consumption and trade of limited goods and services by different agents in a given geographical location. The economic agents can be individuals, businesses, organisations, or governments.
